hawaiian_text: 'Ī aku 'o Nāmakaokapāo'o: "Ua 'ike au, he kanaka nui nō 'o Nāmakaokapāo'o, a ua hele aku nei ma Ko'olau, a 'o wau he inoa nona." 'Ī mai lākou: "'A'ole, 'o 'oe nō, pela ko makou lohe, no laila, e make ana 'oe iā mākou, 'a'ole 'oe e ola." 'Ī aku 'o Nāmakaokapāo'o: "Ho'i aku ho'i hā kākou i lalo e hakakā ai." A hiki lākou i lalo, e hao aku ana 'o Nāmakaokapāo'o, pau loa i ka make, a koe aku ho'okahi kanaka, 'o ia ka i holo aku ā loa'a 'o 'Ama'u ma Waikīkī, 'ōlelo akula ia i ka make o lākou a pau loa, a koe ia i 'āha'ilono e lohe ai 'o 'Ama'u.
gemma-3n-e4b-it-gguf-q4kxl-32k-maui_tran: Nāmakaokapāo'o replied: "I have seen that Nāmakaokapāo'o is a great man, and he has gone to Ko'olau, and that is his name." They replied: "No, it is you alone, that is what we have heard, therefore, you will die at our hands, you will not live." Nāmakaokapāo'o replied: "Let us go down to fight." As they went down, Nāmakaokapāo'o was slashing, leaving only one man, who ran to 'Ama'u at Waikīkī and told him of their deaths, leaving him as a witness to hear of their demise.
gemma-3n-e4b-it-gguf-q4kxl-32k-maui_comm: **Paragraph 8:**• This paragraph is a digression from the story to clarify  that Nā-maka-o-ka-lani (the eyes of the heavens) and  Nā-maka-o-ka-i‘a (the eyes of the fish/man) are two  names used in the lyrics of the prayer chant. Nā maka-o-ka-lani defeats Nā-maka-o-ka-i‘a in the prose,  symbolically representing the defeat of the ‘Ai Kapu  by Christianity.
raw_response:
<translation>Nāmakaokapāo'o replied: "I have seen that Nāmakaokapāo'o is a great man, and he has gone to Ko'olau, and that is his name." They replied: "No, it is you alone, that is what we have heard, therefore, you will die at our hands, you will not live." Nāmakaokapāo'o replied: "Let us go down to fight." As they went down, Nāmakaokapāo'o was slashing, leaving only one man, who ran to 'Ama'u at Waikīkī and told him of their deaths, leaving him as a witness to hear of their demise.</translation>
<commentary>
**Paragraph 13:** • This passage represents a crucial turning point in the narrative, directly following Nāmakaokapāo'o’s initial appearance and subsequent confrontation. It establishes key aspects of his identity – both his perceived greatness/power (a potentially ironic claim) and an association with Ko'olau, a significant region in Hawaiian mythology and history. • The reaction from the other characters is immediate and hostile, indicating fear or opposition to Nāmakaokapāo'o’s presence and actions. Their assertion that he will not live highlights a struggle for dominance and the defense of established norms. 
– The phrase "pela ko makou lohe" (that is what we have heard) is important; it suggests this perception of Nāmakaokapāo'o as a “great man” isn’t based on direct experience but rather on rumors or stories circulating within their community. It adds an element of uncertainty to his identity and could be interpreted as a deliberate misrepresentation by those who oppose him. 
• The act of going "to fight" underscores the conflictual nature of this encounter. Nāmakaokapāo'o is not merely presenting himself; he is actively challenging the status quo, setting up an engagement with opposing forces. • The final sentence, detailing the survival of a single man who then informs 'Ama’u, adds layers of significance:
    – "ʻāha'ilono" (witness) implies this man’s testimony will be crucial in validating or shaping the narrative surrounding Nāmakaokapāo'o’s actions. 
    – The mention of ‘Ama'u is also noteworthy; 'Ama'u, often associated with wisdom and prophetic insight in Hawaiian legends, might act as a judge or arbiter within this conflict. This sets up a potential for moral judgment on the events that have transpired – implying that even though Nāmakaokapāo'o’s actions were destructive, there may be justification. 
– The "slashing" performed by Nāmakaokapāo'o could symbolize his forceful disruption of existing power structures and societal norms. This can be linked to themes of change, upheaval, and the potential dismantling of old ways in favor of new ones. It is a metaphor for destruction – but also creation; the clearing of ground before planting.
</commentary>
reference_translation: Nāmakaokapāo'o said, "I know. Nāmakaokapāo'o is a really big guy. He went to Ko'olau. I'm named after him." The soldiers said, "No, it's you. That's what we heard. So, we're going to kill you. You won't survive." Nāmakaokapāo'o said, "Well, let's go down and fight." When they got down, Nāmakaokapāo'o went to work and killed them all except one man, who ran off and reached 'Ama'u in Waikīkī. He told him about the how they were all killed except for one runner to go and tell 'Ama'u about it.
reference_commentary: **Paragraphs 10—14** • From here, the story seems to extend the allegory of Christianity's defeat over the 'Ai Kapu, with Nāmakaokapāo'o representing progressive Protestant Christianity and everyone apart from his mother, Pōka'ī, and himself, representing Hawaiians' futile attempts to hold onto 'Ai Kapu culture.
